channel.title: Research Highlights | Nature
channel.description: Browse the archive of articles on Nature - Powered by RSSHub

item.title: Food-industry waste finds a second life as bioplastic
item.description:
The protein keratin, the principle ingredient of wool and feathers, can be repurposed as strong, flexible plastic. An abundant waste product of the food industry can be transformed into useful plastics with a flexible chemical process1.

References

  1. Trojanowska, D. J. et al. Matter https://doi.org/10.1016/j.matt.2025.102039 (2025).

    Article  Google Scholar 

Download references

item.title: Iguanas reached Fiji by floating 8,000 kilometres across the sea
item.description:
Genomic analysis suggests that the ancestors of lizards on Fiji today rafted from North America some 30 million years ago. Iguanas colonized Fiji after surviving an 8,000-kilometre sea voyage â€” the longest known oceanic migration by any land-dwelling vertebrate1.

References

  1. Scarpetta, S. G. et al. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA 122, e2318622122 (2025).

    Article  Google Scholar 

Download references

item.title: How extreme lethargy can promote healthy ageing
item.description:
The drop in body temperature that occurs during a torpid state is linked to molecular markers of longer life in mice. A prolonged period of extreme lethargy seems to slow ageing in mice by lowering their core body temperature1.

References

  1. Jayne, L. et al. Nature Aging https://doi.org/10.1038/s43587-025-00830-4 (2025).

    Article  PubMed  Google Scholar 

Download references

item.title: Mega-storm dumps 11 billion tonnes of snow â€• and builds up a melting ice sheet
item.description:
A well-timed atmospheric river dropped enough snow on Greenland for its ice sheet to lose 8% less mass than expected. Powerful storms called atmospheric rivers, which scientists think will become more intense as the planet warms, can replenish Greenlandâ€™s vanishing ice sheet if their timing is right1.

References

  1. Bailey, H. & Hubbard, A. Geophys. Res. Lett. 52, e2024GL110121 (2025).

    Article  Google Scholar 

Download references

item.title: Robotic fingers can tell objects apart by touch
item.description:
Prosthetic appendage uses three layers of touch sensors to accurately differentiate between textures. An innovative prosthetic hand can grasp and distinguish between a wide range of objects with near-human precision1.

References

  1. Sankar, S. et al. Sci. Adv. 11, eadr9300 (2025).

    Article  PubMed  Google Scholar 

Download references

item.title: Bad romance: male octopuses inject deadly venom into their mates
item.description:
The paralysing toxin deployed by the male blue-lined octopus might help to protect him from being eaten. Male blue-lined octopuses inject females with venom during mating to avoid being eaten by their partners, observations suggest1.

References

  1. Chung, W.-S., Kurniawan, N. D., Marshall, N. J. & Cortesi, F. Curr. Biol. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2025.01.027 (2025).

    Article  Google Scholar 

Download references

item.title: The surprising culprit for the loss of huge swathes of tropical forest
item.description:
Analysis of satellite imagery of the Brazilian Amazon, the Congo Basin and New Guinea helps to show that â€˜secondaryâ€™ roads take an outsized toll. The first detailed analysis of â€˜secondary roadsâ€™ â€” those that sprout off the first road cut through an undeveloped forest â€” shows that they can cause forest loss hundreds of times greater than that caused by the original road1.

References

  1. Engert, J. E. et al. Curr. Biol. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2025.02.017 (2025).

    Article  PubMed  Google Scholar 

Download references

item.title: Whoâ€™s likely to wake up from a coma? Brainwaves provide a clue
item.description:
The presence of a pattern called a sleep spindle helps to predict which people will recover from an unresponsive state. A certain pattern of brainwaves recorded during sleep can help to predict whether an unresponsive person who experienced severe brain injury can recover consciousness1.

References

  1. Carroll, E. E. et al. Nature Med. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41591-025-03578-x (2025).

    Article  Google Scholar 

Download references

item.title: Ancient puppets that smile or scowl hint at shared rituals
item.description:
Clay figurines found on top of the remnants of a pyramid in what is now El Salvador might have been used in public ceremonies. At the top of the remains of a large pyramid in Central America, archaeologists discovered ancient puppets with faces that grin or scowl depending on the viewerâ€™s perspective â€” a finding that offers a glimpse into rituals in Mesoamerica1.

References

  1. SzymaÅ„ski, J. & Prejs, G. Antiquity https://doi.org/10.15184/aqy.2025.37 (2025).

    Article  Google Scholar 

Download references

item.title: A super-gel stays supple from âˆ’115 ÂºC to 143 ÂºC
item.description:
A network of two polymers plus sulfuric acid allows a hydrogel to keep its elasticity and softness at extreme temperatures. Jelly-like materials called hydrogels can stay squishy even at extreme temperatures, thanks to a method that locks in their water1.

References

  1. Zhang, X. et al. Science 387, 967â€“973 (2025).

    Article  PubMed  Google Scholar 

Download references

item.title: Just a smidgen of yellow-fever vaccine is enough
item.description:
The standard protective dose is almost 14,000 units, but even 500 units raises antibody levels sufficiently to do the job. Small doses of the yellow-fever vaccine shield adults from the viral disease as effectively as the standard dose, suggests a clinical trial in Kenya and Uganda1.

References

  1. Kimathi, D. et al. N. Engl. J. Med. 392, 788â€“797 (2025).

    Article  PubMed  Google Scholar 

Download references

item.title: Lhasaâ€²s rocks reveal an Australian birthplace
item.description:
Granite from the chunk of Earthâ€™s crust called the Lhasa terrane did not come from India, as had previously been thought, but from much further afield. The block of rock that makes up southern Tibet originally came from what is now Western Australia1 â€” a discovery that could resolve a long-standing geological mystery.

References

  1. Yu, C.-S. et al. Geophys. Res. Lett. 52, e2024GL113338 (2025).

    Article  Google Scholar 

Download references

item.title: Our Galaxyâ€™s central black hole puts on a fireworks show
item.description:
The James Webb Space Telescope uncovered repeated flares from the supermassive object called Sagittarius A*. The supermassive black hole at the centre of our Galaxy is in continuous turmoil, observations made using the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) have revealed1.

References

  1. Yusef-Zadeh, F. et al. Astrophys. J. 980, L35 (2025).

    Article  Google Scholar 

Download references

item.title: Take me home, country toads
item.description:
Cane toads have remarkable navigation abilities, even when their sense of smell and magnetic-sensory systems are compromised. Cane toads â€” sizable, toxic amphibians from Central and South America that have been introduced to Hawaii and Australia â€” can find their way home across long distances. To investigate their homing ability, Daniel Shaykevich at Stanford University in California and his colleagues â€˜toad-nappedâ€™ 62 cane toads (Rhinella marina) on the island of Oâ€˜ahu in Hawaii1. To thoroughly disorient the toads, the team walked them along a winding route for 30âˆ’60 minutes before releasing them up to a kilometre from where theyâ€™d been found.

References

  1. Shaykevich, D. A. et al. Proc. R. Soc. B 292, 20250045 (2025).

    Article  PubMed  Google Scholar 

Download references

item.title: Ancient apex predator tore into hippos with hyena-like teeth
item.description:
Newly discovered species of leopard-sized carnivore lived some 30 million years ago in what is now Egypt. A leopard-sized mammal sat atop its food chain 30 million years ago, hunting early hippos, primates and elephants in what is now Egypt1.

References

  1. Al-Ashqar, S. F. et al. J. Vertebr. Paleontol. https://doi.org/10.1080/02724634.2024.2442472 (2025).

    Article  Google Scholar 

Download references

item.title: Tropical forestâ€™s last old growth is being toppled â€” illegally
item.description:
Satellite imagery helps to identify two hotspots of deforestation in the Atlantic Forest along Brazilâ€™s eastern coast. An area of almost 1,900 square kilometres in Brazilâ€™s imperilled Atlantic Forest was chopped down over the course of a single decade, primarily as a result of agricultural expansion1.

References

  1. Amaral, S. et al. Nature Sustain. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41893-025-01508-w (2025).

    Article  Google Scholar 

Download references

item.title: Newfound bat virus that uses notorious receptor poses â€˜spilloverâ€™ risk
item.description:
The virus is related to the pathogen that causes Middle East respiratory syndrome and capitalizes on the same â€˜entry receptorâ€™ used by SARS-CoV-2. A newly discovered bat coronavirus uses the same portal to enter human cells as the virus that causes COVID-19, raising the risk that it could spark an outbreak in people1.

References

  1. Chen, J. et al. Cell https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cell.2025.01.042 (2025).

    Article  Google Scholar 

Download references

item.title: Low-iridium device speeds progress towards green hydrogen
item.description:
A catalyst that reduces usage of an expensive rare metal could help to make hydrogen fuel affordable. Producing â€˜greenâ€™ hydrogen by splitting water molecules is key to curbing industrial carbon emissions. But the technology is still too expensive to compete with cheap â€” but dirty â€” extraction of hydrogen from natural gas. Thatâ€™s in part because the devices, called electrolysers, that split water require catalysts made of rare elements such as iridium.

References

  1. Shi, W. et al. Science 387, 791â€“796 (2025).

    Article  PubMed  Google Scholar 

Download references

item.title: Bullseye! Galaxy hosts a record-breaking nine starry rings
item.description:
Astronomers trace the striking pattern to an encounter between a big galaxy and a much smaller one some 50 million years ago. The discovery of a galaxy sporting nine concentric rings of stars sheds light on how such ring galaxies form and evolve1.

References

  1. Pasha, I. et al. Astrophys. J. 980, L3 (2025).

    Article  Google Scholar 

Download references

item.title: From farm to pharmacy: gene-edited plants produce a popular supplement
item.description:
Widely grown crops can be bioengineered to make a form of coenzyme Q taken by people seeking a health boost. A painstaking analysis of land-plant evolution has revealed how to engineer crops that produce a popular antioxidant supplement1.

References

  1. Xu, J.-J. et al. Cell https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cell.2025.01.023 (2025).

    Article  Google Scholar 

Download references
